sp.p: I applaud your reſolution; and if you have any occaſion for an auxiliary ſword you know where to find it: in the mean time I think you had better find Lord Frederic and receive fuller information from him; beſides, if you can detain him for the evening it may be of ſingular ſervice to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: The latter motive alone is ſufficient to excite my diligence; for, reſt aſſured, dear Colonel, that whatever my croſs ſtars deſign for me, I heartily wiſh your affairs may feel the influence of a propitious planet.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And be ſatisfied, Sir Charles, my happineſs muſt be incomplete without yours; therefore let us hope the beſt on both ſides. Exeunt ſeverally.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Pleaſe to come this way, Sir, and Mrs. Buſy will wait on you immediately.

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: Very well, I ſhall attend the lady's leiſure, child, la, la, la, (ſings)

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: What an impudent fellow is this (aſide) your honour won't be angry if I aſk a queſtion?

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: No, not at all, my dear.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Pray did your honour ever hear of a brother of mine, one Thomas Ruelle, a ſoldier?

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: No, child; nor was it at all likely I ſhould, unleſs he had been in my own company; we officers ſeldom know any thing of the private, but that they are men, or look like ſuch; we who bear commiſſions are entirely among ourſelves, my dear, la, la, la, la (ſings)

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! I can hold no longer— well ſaid captain Fuſee; why, ſirrah, could you imagine that fine cloaths, a bag wig, and quality airs, could hide that ſweet gunpowder face from my knowledge?

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: Pox o'this diſcerning jade, I ſhall infallibly be blown up (aſide)

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Captain! does your well-tried aſſurance fail you—pray what ſcheme, what military trick is your honour upon in this diſguiſe?

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: Since 'tis in vain to diſſemble, I'll e'en tell you—my maſter wanting to get the old lady of this houſe off his hands, has put me into maſquerade —I have had but one conference, and yet, by the help of mother Sly, want nothing but a parſon to finiſh the affair.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Mighty well! and what then becomes of all your fine ſpun proteſtations to me, Mr. Saucebox?

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: Why you know, Mrs. Ruelle, Pyramus and Thiſbe never loved ſo well; but you was allways throwing dependance and poverty in my teeth, ſo I thought it high time to mend myſelf.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: A very fine come-off indeed; but I'll ſpoil your maſter's project, and your's, Mr. Impudence, I will, and diſcover all this moment.

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: Nay, dear Ruelle, don't be ſo cruel as that neither.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p:
Dear Ruelle—not ſo much familiarity, puppy, you and your maſter are a couple of deceitful
forſworn rakehells, and ought to be expoſed.

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: What will nothing pacify you? nothing bridle that harmonious tongue?

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: No, wretch—not all the eloquence you have.

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: Why then let my maſter ſpeak—he deſired me to preſent his compliments and this (gives a purſe) the firſt I had no ſcruple to give, but the latter I thought to have ſaved.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Very honeſt indeed, noble captain, and like the reſt of your tricks—let me ſee—hum— hum—ten guineas! why ah, theſe are compliments worth receiving, and ſhows the Colonel knows how to ſpeak moſt feelingly—Yet, after all, muſt I not only loſe ſo ſweet a ſwain, but, as I have read in ſome play, be made myſelf the inſtrument? muſt I not only die, but plunge the dagger in my heart myſelf? this is indeed refining on calamity.

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: Tender loving ſoul—I never thought her ſo fond as this—poor pretty ſoft rogue, let me kiſs off thy tears.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Tears!—ha! ha! ha! ha! not ſo fooliſh as that neither, good Mr. Captain; and ſince your ſincerity is brought to light, I'll ſhow you that I was prepared againſt it.

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: What does the jade mean?

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Mean, why I mean there's a ſea captain, worth ten thouſand pounds, my maſter's brother-in-law, whoſe heart I have ſo engaged, by helping him to ſome bowls of punch more than Sir Scrapeall allowed, that he has given me ſeveral kind glances, ſqueezed my hands almoſt to a jelly; and ſworn, if I have a mind, he'll get a parſon to ſplice us together to-morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: Oh, ſnap him by all means; and when we have made the double match, you and I can be on better terms than ever, Mrs, Ruelle.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Stand off, jackanapes, and learn a proper diſtance to your betters—you and your old madam, muſt not put yourſelf on a footing with a real Captain's Lady; for my meſs-mate, as he calls himſelf, though he's but a ſcurvy original, has the recommendation of a fine gilded frame to ſet him off—I ſhall ſo gall madam Fuſee by taking place of her—for I am reſolved, when once Mrs Starboard, to hold my own; to pay as many viſits, to wear as fine cloaths, and have as grand a route as any city lady of them all.

sp.speaker: Fuſee
sp.p: Hoity toity! what whirligigs fortune has planted in the wench's head already.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Captain, to your arms, the General's at hand. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: Sblood! this miſtreſs of mine has the ſame effect upon me that a labelled bottle has upon the ſtomach of a ſick man;—but I muſt take the doſe to cure the conſumptive ſtate of my pockets.
Captain, your very moſt humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: Madam, your eternal ſlave.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Lard, Captain, I am moſt infinitely concerned at the rudeneſs of having made you wait ſo long, and ſcarce know how to apologize; but my poor neighbour, Mrs. Dolefull, who has a ſad fellow of a huſband, came to conſult me, and would not let me ſtir.

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: Madam, though your abſence to me is worſe than riding the wooden horſe, ſtanding upon the picket, being tied up to the halberts, or even running the gantelope, upon ſo good-natured an occaſion of delay as comforting a diſtreſſed neighbour, I muſt be not only ſatisfied, but pleaſed alſo at the beauty of your mind, as much as I am captivated with the beauty of your perſon, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Sir, the force and delicacy of your compliment, makes me bluſh; I profeſs it does—yet who would ever truſt a man after what my good friend Mrs. Sly related of the Colonel.

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: Oh, name him not, madam, the young fellow is indeed plauſible enough, but nothing of a ſoldier except the title—good friends, no merit; and as to gallantry, I know he makes it his buſineſs to boaſt of favours from the ladies.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, I defy him there, he could never boaſt of favours from me but in an honourable way—I don't flaunt about with profligate young fellows—no—I act with diſcretion—I have an unſullied character to ſupport—ay, ay—if ſome forward flirting minx's of the age, would take half ſo much care of reputations as they do of complexions, there would not be ſuch wicked and ſenſual doings.

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: Very true, madam—raviſhing ſentiments —killing eyes—let me ſwear by the horrors of war, that though I have had my hat taken off by a four and twenty pounder; though my beard has been cloſe ſinged by the flaſh of a cannon; tho' my teeth have been picked with bayonets; though a whole platoon of muſquet balls has paſſed thro' my body; and though I have been three times blown up on the forlorn hope; yet never did my heart feel ſuch palpitation as thoſe charms have cauſed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Oh dear, that's a moſt powerful impreſſion —well, military gentlemen undergo great hardſhip—and I preſume you are forced to kill people in your own defence, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p:
Certainly, madam—why now in the battle of—of—pſhaw, pox, I have been in ſo many I don't know which it was—but this ſingle arm demoliſhed two French Marqui's, four Counts,
and above a dozen rank and file; but ſuch bloody deeds are at an end; the promiſe of your fair hand, madam, has made me determine to throw up my commiſſion.

sp.speaker: Mrs B.
sp.p: Obliging and tender to the laſt degree.

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: But I ſhan't quit the ſervice of my country entirely; I have a borough waiting for me, and I believe I ſhall accept of it—but, madam, ſay when ſhall the ſpecial licence, I have obtained, take effect.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: You are ſo zealous, Sir, but ſince you are determined e'en when you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: To-morrow morning then, my fair, the chaplain of our regiment ſhall attend, and I'll fly upon the wings of love to give you notice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Dear Sir, you are ſo irreſiſtably perſuading —I ſhall certainly attend your call.

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: Tranſporting ſound!

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Bleſs me, I hear ſomebody coming; and I would keep all ſnug till things are done.

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: Madam your words plant ſilence on my lips—ten thouſand ſoft adieus.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: The ſame let me return—remember to-morrow Exeunt ſeverally.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Colonel you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip's moſt obedient—pray, madam, was not that Lord Frederic who parted from you juſt now?

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: The ſame, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: So then here's anticipation againſt me. (aſide)

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: I profeſs, Colonel, your coming has given me great pleaſure; I began to almoſt deſpair of you; and my route would have been as inſipid in your abſence as a humdrum ſociety of country-folks ſet to cards in a winter's evening.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip does me particular honour.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Well, after all this matrimony is a very ſad thing — Siberia, I think you called it, did not you, Colonel?—notwithſtanding which, my ſiſter I believe will ſhortly travel to that deſart clime—well, I hope ſhe may find it a pleaſanter ſpot than I have done.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your ſiſter, madam!

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Yes, truly—Lord Frederic, tho' his firſt viſit, I find has hinted ſomething that way, and my ſiſter ſeems to have no objection.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! 'tis as I feared (aſide) —this is a very ſudden affair indeed, madam; but perhaps the match may not be ſo agreeable to Sir Scrapeall, and ſhe can't marry without his conſent.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: That's true, as you ſay, Colonel; but I believe his generous worſhip conſiders her as a ſaleable piece of goods, and would be glad to make a profitable affair of his conſent.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That hint may be of uſe to me (aſide) I ſhould hardly have ſuppoſed your Ladyſhip's ſiſter capable of ſo precipitate a compliance.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Why its a little out of the common courſe, but the impreſſions of love are lightning-winged, and very variable in their flight—witneſs thoſe tender expreſſions, and the profuſion of regard you have laviſhed upon me, Colonel— though any woman might be vain of the conqueſt, yet I never ſought it: however I am really concerned you ſhould be ſo much in love with me; but what can I poſſibly do?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A hopeful theme for my perplexity (aſide) I am much debtor to your Ladyſhip's humanity, and muſt be content to ſigh away my paſſion in abſence.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p:
Abſence; nay that looks like abſolute deſpair —and deſpair is a very ſad thing—I ſhould grieve to be the cauſe of it—come, who
knows, Colonel, my agreeable lord and maſter can't live always, and when he's gone—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I wiſh I was gone with all my heart (aſide) your Ladyſhip is ſo much in the right, that hope, tho' ever ſo diſtant, beams cheering rays; but if Lord Frederic ſhould prevail, and blaſt—

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Lord Frederic! why you know Colonel, he addreſſes my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: True, madam—he does ſo—I—I miſtook —you'll excuſe my confuſion.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Poor man, I proteſt I pity him, I never ſaw him ſo much affected before, but I can't help the bewitching power of my eyes (aſide) — nay, Colonel, be comforted, within the bounds of honour you may command me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I can't in the leaſt doubt your Ladyſhip's goodneſs, but ardent love is impatient of delay and fearful of defeat, therefore if your ſiſter ſhould reſolve to check my wiſhes and favour a rival.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: My ſiſter—you don't imagine ſhe ſhall direct my choice.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, madam—I did not mean that—but then in caſe—I ſay that if your Ladyſhip—a— oons, I don't know what to ſay.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: I ſee my ſtaying does but perplex him the more—humanity inſtructs me to withdraw that he may have time to recover—well, Colonel, perhaps the company will compoſe your ſpirits and baniſh the train of impertinent thoughts which ſo buſily intrude upon your quiet—I'll leave you with Lord Frederic till we ſit down to cards, and I muſt poſitively inſiſt upon your being of my party. Exit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Pox o'party, cards, and company; every moment till I ſee Emmeline is torture.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p:
Well, Colonel, I muſt ſay you are a gentleman of very difficult taſte, for, as I remember,
you told me that Emmeline was very middling in point of beauty, now I think her exquiſite • y charming.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: It may be ſo, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: may be ſo—nay it is ſo, Colonel— I profeſs myſelf the Lady's champion, my ſword is devoted to her ſervice as well as my heart, and I ſhall eſteem any inſinuation againſt her charms as high treaſon againſt the queen of beauty.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip is very rapturous upon the occaſion, and I don't doubt but your ſword is as ready as you ſpeak it; however, ſince matters are come ſo far, I muſt take the liberty to inform you that the Lady does not ſtand in need of your knight errantry, for I have profeſſed my ſervice, which having been accepted, I cannot now decline.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Hey day! why certainly we are got to croſs purpoſes; what a perſon of Colonel Parapet's taſte interfere with ſuch an odd family as this, and devote himſelf to a young Lady who can only make a tolerable citizen's wife, on whom quality would ſit very aukwardly? ha! ha! ha! ha! now I ſhall take the pains to poliſh this rough diamond.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip is facetious, but to daſh your lordſhip's hopes, know that a previous claim to the Lady's favour has been made by me, and countenanced by her, which I preſume, my Lord, will put an end to your pretenſions.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Put an end to my pretenſions! as ſoon to my life, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: If that be your reſolution, my Lord, I know but of one deciſion—you have, in appearance, an excellent ſword, and I cannot doubt either your Lordſhip's ſkill or courage in the uſe of it.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p:
A very rational method of argument, truly; right military logic, and in regard of us young fellows may be ſalutary, our conſtitutions are too ſanguine, and breathing a vain muſt be
uſeful, ſo I ſhan't baulk your reſolution—come Sir. (draws.)

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Spoke with the generous pleaſantry of true courage, and ſtrict honour, it will be ſome pleaſure, if I ſhould fall, to fall by ſo brave a hand (draws)

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Let me warn you, Colonel, to keep at a diſtance; for there is not a man in England could ſtand long before me at cloſe quarters.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You are particularly generous, my Lord, but I am prepared for all events.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Very well, Sir—come on then—yet hold—two points we have forgot: it won't be ſo decent to throw the family into confuſion with our private animoſity, and if in this combat the Lady's favourite, which ever it is, ſhould fall, the conqueror will have no cauſe for trumph; ſo that being ſomewhat between hawk and buzzard, I think the Lady ſhould be conſulted; and if ſhe declines an explanation we can but appeal to our ſwords at laſt.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: True, my Lord, and on that footing let me have the honour to call myſelf your Lordſhip's friend.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I cordially embrace your propoſal, and here the Lady comes moſt opportunely; if you'll open the caſe you ſhall have all the juſtice imaginable.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Colonel, your humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Madam, your moſt obedient—I am ſorry there ſhould be any occaſion to deſire an explanation of what, for particular reaſons, I have endeavoured to conceal; but his Lordſhip informing me of acl •• he either has or intends to put in for your favour, I am under the neceſſity, madam, of requeſting that you will do juſtice to the previous right I aſſert.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Right! Colonel!—I proteſt you aſtoniſh me! I am an entire ſtranger to the meaning of this formal addreſs.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A ſtranger, madam!

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Quite ſo I aſſure you, Sir—you talk of right, and favour, and juſtice; but upon what cauſe, and between what parties I really cannot conceive.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: How, madam!

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: And if I did, not having been uſed to the law 'tis very probable I might not be able to decide; however the curioſity incident to my ſex, induces me to requeſt an explanation.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am thunderſtruck!—is it poſſible, madam, you can need an explanation?

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Come, come, Colonel, this affected ſurpriſe, and theſe diſtant inſinuations are unfair, I'll deal more candidly, and ſet the Lady right at onee—you muſt know, madam, that happening to mention the impreſſion your charms have made upon my heart, this gentleman, my friend, declared that he had already preferred his addreſſes—

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: What! his addreſſes to me!

sp.speaker: L. Char.
sp.p: Yes, madam, and that you had received them moſt favourably.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Favourably—is it poſſible you could advance this, Colonel!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why, madam, did you not?

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: So upon this ſuppoſition, the colonel very kindly propoſed his cutting my throat, or my cutting his; and if you had not appeared, madam, like the dove with the olive branch, I know not what might have been the conſequence, for our reſolutions ſeemed very terrible on both ſides.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip is very fanciful and merry; but I am not in a mood of temper to bear ſneers at preſent.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p:
Nay now, Colonel, you are quite
too ſevere, that you'll neither allow me to love p • attle nor laugh, ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Fire and fury!

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: So, ſo, ſo, now the myſtery begins to clear up; and I perceive that what appeared rudeneſs is merely the unhappy effects of frenzy.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Sdeath! madam! frenzy?
Moſt certainly; could any thing elſe have introduced ſuch romantic chimaer • s, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Madam, this affected ignorance of what you too well know, may prove inſincerity, but cannot add to the reputation of candor and judgement —choice is undoubtedly free; but that choice once fixed, does not admit of alteration without ſome material reaſon.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Ay, there, Sir, I entirely come in with your opinion had any ſuch choice been made: but I ſee you are quite too violent for argument, therefore I think it will be moſt prudent to retire.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Hold, madam.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Nay, no violence.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Sdeath! Sir, dare you interpoſe? (draws)

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Ah! (ſcreams)

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Sheath your ſword, Colonel, I ſhan't fight a lunatic, poſitively.

div.stage: ENTER LADY BRAINLESS and MRS BUSY haſtily.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Bleſs me what was the reaſon of that ſcream? —a ſword drawn—ah, I ſhall certainly faint.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: The Colonel—my blood boils at the fellow.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: So, I ſhall have the whole crew upon me, (aſide)

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: For heav'ns ſake, Emmeline, what is the meaning of all this?

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p:
Only the Colonel, ſiſter, who becauſe I
would not confeſs being in love with him, very heroically intended to murther his Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: What! you in love with him?

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Yes, truly, and talks of having paid his addreſſes in form; aſſerts they were favourably received; and charges me with inſincerity.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: What were his profeſſions to make a cat's paw of me—my pride is hurt (aſide)

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Ah, have a care child—he's a moſt dangerous fellow, he would have impoſed upon me if he could.

sp.speaker: Col
sp.p: Yes, I ſhall have it now, and ſoundly too. (aſide)

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: How, Sir! did you make love to my ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: To your ſiſter, madam—

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Did not you ſigh, and vow, and ſwear to me perjur'd wretch?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: To you!—

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: What was that your delicate taſte?

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Where was your diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Oons! I had no diſcretion to run myſelf into ſuch a—

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Such a what, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, ſuch a what?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why, ſuch, ſuch—'ſdeath! no words can paint my condition.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Have not you attempted to aſperſe my ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Did you not ſtrive to delude me?

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I find you are a general lover, Colonel, ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And what then, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. Brain
sp.p: Why then you are a deceitful treacherous hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: A baſe, deſigning, ſcurvy fellow.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am infinitely obliged to you, ladies.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: You are an inveigler of hearts.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: A breaker of vows.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: A vile betrayer.

sp.speaker: Mrs B.
sp.p: A monſter of prey.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Mighty well, mighty well, truly; I have brought myſelf to a fine paſs here; bubbled of my miſtreſs, jeer'd by a coxcomb, baited like a bear by a couple of—well ladies I hope your lungs may be the better for this breathing whatever my ears may have ſuffered; for you, madam, who have ſo very ſhort a memory, or ſuch a weathercock heart, I have only to repent the knowledge of ſo much beauty and falſhood; his facetious Lordſhip I may meet in a fitter time and place. (going.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What for you to begin again! 'ſdeath! I'd ſooner ſtand at the mouth of a charged cannon with a lighted match at the touch-hole. runs off.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Poſitively he ſhan't eſcape ſo eaſy. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Eaſy; no, no, he ſhall have t'other ſaſarara before he gets off. Exit.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! let's follow and have a little more of it.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: With all my heart—tho' I almoſt begin to pity him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Sir! have a care—I'm afraid you'll fall.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: No, no, my little pilot—you know the ſong—ſteddy, boys, ſteddy—thof I do carry too much canvas, and ſail gunwale too, in a rolling ſea I ſhall weather the gale—but ſtrike my topſails, what are all theſe freſh-water paſſengers that are come aboard our ſhip, we ſha'nt have ſtowage for them.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: You mean, Sir, the company that are coming to my Lady's route.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: Route what's that?

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Why, Sir, a great many ladies and gentlemen who meet to play at cards all night.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: An that be their trim, ſpring my bowſprit, if I were maſter of the veſſel but I'd heave all ſuch live lumber overboard—but what ſay you, my little pinace, to that ſame voyage I was talking about? an you like it I'll heave out a hawſer of love, and take you in tow for the port of matrimony.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: La, Sir, I am afraid you only want to delude me; I have heard ſuch ſtrange things of you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: Gentlemen! ſtrike my flag not ſo bad as that neither—I'm a ſailor, my heart of gold, not like one of your land pirates, who fight under falſe colours, and trade to horn-fair; we at ſea ſtick to our ſweethearts as we do to our ſhips, as long as they can ſwim—ſo if you like to ſwing in my hammock ſay the word; I'll cruize for a parſon tomorrow morning, that ſhall ſplice us faſt together as if we were at moorings with the beſt bower and cable of a firſt—

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: To be ſure, Sir, you are very good; and I muſt own have won my heart; but I am afraid that Sir Scrapeall will be angry.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: And what then? think you he's to have ſteering of me?—blow me up, Dick Starboard has not been ſo many leagues on the ſalt ſea to be commanded by any land-lubber of them all.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, but your family may think it ſuch a diſgrace; and I would not have it ſaid for the whole world—you know, Sir, I am but a waiting-woman.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p:
A waiting-woman! and what then? board me I was but a ſwabber myſelf, ſo there's family for family, ho! ho! ho!—meſs 'tis not always ſafe to ſail in your gilded ginger-bread pleaſure-boats
—I like your model and trim; and look, d'ye ſee, if you'll chuſe me maſter, I'll navigate you while there's compaſs, helm, and ſea-ſtore.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I don't know what to ſay to you; you are ſo fond, and ſo engaging, and ſo ſincere, that, excuſe my bluſhes—I can't poſſibly refuſe you any thing.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: Why that's well ſaid—this ſeals my commiſſion (kiſſes her and ſtumbles forward) avaſt, avaſt, meſs I ſhipp'd a head-ſea on my poop there, and had much ado to come to rights again—well, my little frigate, I'll clear out of the canonical cuſtomhouſe, and ſteer away with you for Merryland to-morrow morning—wind and weather permitting —meſs thou ſhalt be rigg'd as fine, and ſwagger with any quality yacht of them all; and ſo, d'yee ſee, if you'll toſs me up ſuch another can of flip as I had juſt now, and make a trip with it to my hammock, when its my watch I'll do the ſame for you.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Sir, I thought you might want ſomething, ſo I kept the keys; Sir Scrapeall ordered Timothy to take them to bed, but I inſiſted on having them.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: Well ſaid, again, my little trimmer— run me aſhore an it had not been for thee I might have lived on rope's ends and four ſmall beer in this here ſhip; but choak my pumps, and ſcuttle my bottom, an ſhe'll ſwim long—ſo many maſters and never a ſteerſman, ſhe'll ſoon be on the ſhallows. (going joſtles the ſide wing) So, ſo, bring the land marks to bear Dick Starboard, and double the head-lands, ſeaman like.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: There, Sir, you are at your chamber-door.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p:
Enough, enough, enough, I'll caſt anchor
in Slumber-bay in leſs than half a glaſs.—Yo, ho, meſs-mate, bear a hand, and don't forget the flip, d'ye hear. Exit.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.p: HA! ha! ha! ha! a pretty ſituation you had got into among the females; however, my diſcovery of the pretended Lord Frederic, has occaſioned a conſiderable revolution in your countenance, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ay, and in my heart too, Sir Charles; but I am impatient to know the method of your diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Know then I went in ſearch of Lord Frederic, and being told he was gone to Lady Brainleſs's route, I followed; where I was ſo thoroughly mortified with an account of Lady Charlotte's marriage, that to collect my ſpirits, I retired and took a moon-light turn in the garden.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A proper place, and fit ſeaſon, for melancholy reflection.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: I had not been long there when her maſquerading Ladyſhip, and Emmeline, came down a neighbouring walk, enjoying aloud the perplexity they had given us; encouraged by the ſubject, I drew near, and received conviction that your rival is no other than my miſtreſs, who concluded with remarking, that ſhe thought they had played upon us ſufficiently.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Yes, truly, I think they have; ſo long that I began to be moſt horridly out of tune—but
prithee what could be at the bottom of this Quixote ſcheme?

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: To gain ſome aſſurance of our ſincerity, which, after laughing at us a little, they ſeemed ſatisfied with.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Dear Sir Charles, let me embrace you, ſo prudent and ſpirited a deſign makes the little gipſies ten times dearer than ever—did you let them know the diſcovery?

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Not for the world—I haſtened from the garden, joined the company ſome minutes before them, ſhook off all concern, was unuſually gay, and gallanted Lady Betty Ombre ſo warmly, that poor Lord Charles was, in his turn, utterly diſcontented.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! braviſſimo! that was turning the tables upon them with ſtrict juſtice; and I think it would not be amiſs to have a little more of it

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: By all means, I ſought you for that purpoſe, I am to call at Sir Scrapeall's this morning, and would have you drop in occaſionally; for as the politicians play'd a double game into each others hands, it is but fit we ſhould return like for like.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: With all my heart, it will be notable revenge; miſchief on't had your diſcovery been made a little ſooner it might have ſaved me five thouſand pounds for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why in the heat of my paſſion, I went to the Knight, made known my paſſion for Emmeline, and offered half her fortune for his conſent.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Ha!—a ſubſtantial compliment to the Lady, Colonel, but we muſt try to ſettle matters otherwiſe—but come the hour calls me to the citizen's —I'll lead the van, do you bring up the rear.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Fear not, I am ever punctual to my orders.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Dear Lady Charlotte, I am concerned to ſee your natural vivacity ſo much diſconcerted by a ſlight ſuppoſition.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Slight ſuppoſition! alas, Emmeline, in your caſe you don't ſee with the eyes of love, elſe you would put another conſtruction upon Sir Charles's behaviour.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: I admit there was ſomething extraordinary; but the feelings he confeſſed when you told him of the intended marriage were ſtrong and ſincere; the gaiety he afterwards aſſumed was, if I judge right, a ſlight veil occaſionally thrown over a gloomy heart.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: I can't think ſo—forced ſpirits are eaſily ſeen through, and ſuch could never have carried him ſo far as to gallant that forward ſhallow piece of coquetry, Lady Betty.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: There, I muſt acknowledge, he was ſomewhat myſterious.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Would I had not taken this diſguiſe, though it has been ſo far uſeful as to prove the ſincerity of your lover, it has only purchaſed pain for me—I cannot blame Sir Charles—the fault is mine—I have acted like a fooliſh boy, who plays with and teizes a favourite bird, till breaking bondage, it takes wing never to be recalled; dear friend what ſtep ſhall I take?

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: I would hope the beſt: ſtill you know by appointment he will ſoon be here, ſound him a little further and I dare believe he will yet fulfill my good opinion of him.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I would indulge that hope, but ſtrong doubts preſs forward to exclude it.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: I ſee him coming, and ſhall leave you to a private conference. Exit.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Sir Charles good morning—I have, according to promiſe, prepared a letter for my ſiſter Charlotte, wherein I have enlarged upon your previous pretenſions as much as poſſible.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I am infinitely obliged to your Lordſhip; but upon ſecond thought, I have determined not to offend Lady Charlotte by a viſit.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Your reſolution ſo warmly urged is very ſoon changed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Why, my Lord, upon cool deliberation, I think it better not to proceed any further in the affair; 'tis poſſible I might have interpreted the Lady's good nature too partially in my own favour; and as freedom of choice is undoubtedly juſt, it would be rude and cruel to interrupt her preſent ſcheme of happineſs.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: You are of a very happy diſpoſition, Sir Charles, that can ſo ſoon, and ſo coolly, reconcile an affair which ſeemed ſo intereſting—

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I am tolerably philoſophical in theſe matters; beſides, to own the truth, I had, amongſt other converſation, talked ſo much of love to Lady Charlotte that I fancied our hearts engaged when there was nothing meant, I believe, but a little faſhionable gallantry.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
Sir Char.
sp.p: Nay, my Lord, ſhe's too much a fine Lady to be in any danger that way—
Colonel Parrapet your moſt humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Sir Charles, yours: my Lord I kiſs your hand.

sp.speaker: L. Char.
sp.p: Sir, I don't think your behaviour and our laſt parting admit of ſuch familiarity.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Nay, my Lord, I came on purpoſe to ſolicit pardon; too free a glaſs had fluſtered my temper without the leaſt intention of offence; acknowledgement of error is, I know, ſufficient to a man of honour, but I muſt confeſs myſelf a little puzzled for an apology to this Lady.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Sir Charles, your ſervant—oh! the Colonel —may we hope that night and reflection, Sir, have given your thoughts a calm?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Moſt certainly, madam, and I hope your good nature will grant indulgence to unlimited confeſſion, eſpecially as I am come to make all attonement poſſible by offering any aſſiſtance wh • ch may promote his Lordſhip's happineſs and yours.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: So this ſwain is changed about too.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Your condeſcenſion is very forward, Sir, but I preſume his Lordſhip can take care of his own happineſs without your aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Doubtleſs, madam—but if I could any way contribute—

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you are exceeding liberal and courtly in your profeſſions and promiſes, I can witneſs that.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: How ſo madam? for by your own declaration I never had the honour of promiſing or profeſſing to you —

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, Sir, but I believe if you had, you are very capable of forſwearing it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Oh dear madam, I am ſorry you have ſo terrible an opinion of me; but I perceive this ſubject grows too intereſting—adſo, I had almoſt forgot to tell you, Sir Charles, that I met Lady Betty Ombre juſt now, and to uſe her own phraſe, ſhe dies till ſhe ſees you.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I ſhall go diſtracted. (aſide)

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Colonel I am obliged to you for delivering ſo kind a meſſage; and from ſo accompliſhed a Lady; when your match with her ſiſter Lady Frances is compleated; of friends we ſhall become brothers.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Confident! faith • eſs wretches! (aſide)

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That will be double pleaſure; pray, madam, are you intimate with the family of the Ombre • s

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: I don't know, I can't tell—inſolent tormenting man. (aſide)

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip will be happy in an acquaintance there—Sir Charles will introduce you, and if your Lordſhip's choice was not already fixed upon this Lady, there is a third ſiſter who has a moſt bewitching pair of eyes.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I can hold no longer.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: A very dangerous pair of ſparklers, indeed, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Sir, you are a villain.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: And, Sir, you are the worſt of villains.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Amazing!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Wonderful!

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Oh that I were a man for juſtice ſake.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: And I too.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: And I too—what ſelf betrayed, ha! ha! ha! ha! this is more than I expected, and haſtens the comedy to a concluſion—what think you ladies, have we ballanced the account of perplexity or not?

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Ladies!

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Nay, never look ſtrange; your ſcheme was well laid, and had not chance directed me to a moon-light walk in the garden laſt night, we might have continued food for mirth at the expence of our peace.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: I am glad its no worſe. (aſide)

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I am ſo confus'd and ſo pleas'd, I know not what to ſay. (aſide)

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: The palpitation of our hearts will, I hope, ladies, make this treſpaſs on your patience appear excuſable.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, ſince it is in vain to deny, I admit your diſcovery, and cannot but acknowledge your treatment has been founded on ſtrict juſtice.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Spoke with your uſual candour and generoſity, lady Charlotte, and hence let mutual confidence enſue; as to you, madam, I have Sir Scrapeall's promiſe to make you mine.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: So! ſo! Here's counter-working— was it fair to undermine me; but pray how did you prevail upon the knight.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: By the rhetoric of five thouſand pounds; that is, offering to ſurrender half the Lady's fortune.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Generous indeed!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And had it been twenty times as much I ſhould have only thought it a fit ſacrifice to ſo much merit.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: An excellent proof of diſintereſted love, Colonel—but you are outbid, for I propoſed to take the Lady without any fortune at all; and am to have the honeſt Citizen's written conſent within.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Contemptible reptile!

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! upon my honour, Colonel, you have been fairly outſoldiered, beat at your own weapons.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: And poor I ſet up at auction to the beſt bidder.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! ha! even ſo, Emmeline; but all for the better, I hope—oh! I ſee Lady Brainleſs, I have ſome buſineſs with her in my
Lordly capacity and ſhall beg of you to retire.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: You command us madam.

div.stage: Exeunt Emme. Sir Cha. and Col.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Now muſt I play a part ſeverely kind in hopes of good effects, your Ladyſhip's moſt obedient.
My Lord, your humble ſervant,

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip had a bad run at cards laſt night.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Oh terrible! my Lord! it ſeemed as if fortune had determined to croſs me.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Were not ſuch things common, madam, in matters of chance, they would preſs hard upon patience—I think your Ladyſhip loſt fifteen hundred pounds? one thouſand to me, and five hundred to Lord Robert Whiſt?

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Thereabouts, I believe, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I am ſorry to urge your Ladyſhip; but being myſelf a good deal out of caſh at preſent, and having a bill of eight hundred to pay this forenoon, ſhould be obliged to you for the trifle depending between us.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Really, my Lord, your demand takes me rather at a diſadvantage.

sp.speaker: L. Charl.
sp.p: You know, madam, it is not like the impertinent bill of a troubleſome mechanic for work done, or goods delivered, it is a debt of honour; and ſuch you know, takes place of all other payments among people of faſhion.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: That's very true, my Lord, and I would always act up to the faſhion, but inclination muſt give way where ability is totally wanting; and though Sir Scrapeall deals in caſh I am almoſt as bare as if he was not worth a ſingle ſhilling.

sp.speaker: L. Charl.
sp.p: If this be the caſe I find I ventured real againſt imaginary ſums, and muſt therefore be more cautious of my company.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Really, my Lord, there is much leſs politeneſs in that inuendo than I ſhould have expected from a man of faſhion.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Politeneſs, madam, is very well upon particular occaſions; but in gaming there is no ſuch thing, we win of whom and when we can; like death, it cuts off all diſtinction of rank, relations and friends, and ſtakes muſt be paid, or perſons expoſed; but as your Ladyſhip is a fine woman matters ſhould be made as eaſy as poſſible, and if—

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: If what, my Lord!

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I preſume there could not be much love in your match with Sir Scrapeall—I have conceived a paſſion, give it ſuitable return, and let the thouſand pounds—

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Inſolent man, no more; what part of my conduct, tho' perhaps ungarded, could encourage ſo groſs an inſult—gratify your malice, expoſe the ſum due, and ſet me up the ſport of laughing libertines, I'll bear all patiently, as the fruit and puniſhment of my own indiſcretion, ſecure in this pleaſing reflection, that tho' you publiſh my poverty you cannot taint my virtue.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Come, come, madam, Colonel Parapet would have received a gentler anſwer.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: No, my Lord, there you are miſtaken alſo; for though that gentleman may have been allowed a particular intimacy, and may have improved or miſconſtrued appearances, he muſt be a conſumate villain if ever he dropped a prejudicial inſinuation; for let me ſay to you, to him, and all the world, that however I have dipped into follies, the vices of life could never make me a proſelyte.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p:
'Tis as I always thought, dear Lady Brainleſs, theſe juſt and noble ſentiments force off falſe appearances, and reveal me, inſtead of a gaming
Lord, your diſintereſted and inviolable friend Charlotte Bloom.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Lady Charlotte! why then this diſguiſe! or why would friendſhip alarm ſuch painful ſenſations.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: As to the motive of this appearance you ſhall know in due time—why I have wounded your delicate feeling was to awaken a ſenſe of what you juſtly call follies, which have long obſcured many valuable qualifications, and ſubjected you to the reproach of ſeveral who have l • ſs real merit, but more external caution.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Dear Lady Charlotte, I ſhall be ever debtor to your kind opinion and friendly deſign; reflection tells me I have given too juſt cauſe for cenſure, yet not without ſome plea of juſtification.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I am certain of it, your moſt diſproportionate marriage, if not an entire excuſe, is at leaſt a powerful palliation.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Marriage; there you have ſaid all at once, thoſe who ſhould have ſtudied and judged better for my future happineſs warmly urged the match; young and unexperienced I was, allured by the hopes of a title, and unlimited command; ever ſince I have been almoſt hourly rendered unhappy by the ſelfiſh and perverſe temper of Sir Scrapeall, which has occaſioned me to deſpiſe and croſs him in every particular; and moſt of my extravagncies have been more calculated for killing time, than any pleaſure—pity me, dear Charlotte, for I find my ſcheme of life widely different from what I wiſh, and yet in ſelf defence I am obliged to follow it; when avarice, jealouſy, and diſcord prevail at home, peace muſt be ſought abroad.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I have no reaſon to doubt your friendſhip —but tell me, did the Colonel uſe any freedom with my character?

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: No, upon my honour, what I hinted was from obſervation laſt night; and repeated to alarm you, tho' I ſincerely believe you meant nothing.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Your interpretation, my friend, is kind and juſt; I own my horrid ſituation made me fond of his engaging converſation; and female vanity was flattered in ſome compliments he paſſed upon me, nothing more, I aſſure you, and yet, now I look back, ſuch gallant trifling is like ſporting on the unſtedfaſt margin of a lucid ſtream, where while we admire the beautiful reflection in its liquid boſom, one falſe ſtep hurries us to certain deſtruction.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Your ſimilitude, my friend, is fancifully juſt; but we are too grave, Sir Charles, the Colonel and Emmeline are but in the next room, ſhall we join them and prattle away gloomy ideas.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Excuſe me for the preſent, dear Lady Charlotte, the reflections you have awakened render my ſpirits unfit for converſation, therefore give me leave to retire—think for me, gentle friend, and if any means can be found to free from, or alleviate my bondage, I promiſe that future conduct ſhall prove my errors the effect of diſagreeable circumſtances; of a tormented, but not a diſhoneſt heart. Exit.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: How good a heart may inadvertently be led into unfavourable appearance?

div.stage: ENTER SIR CHARLES COLONEL and EMMELINE.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Knowing your deſign. Lady Charlotte, I ventured to make theſe gentlemen ear witneſſes of the work of reformation, and they admire it vaſtly.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I am glad of it; and hope you will all join to ſet her Ladyſhip free.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Sdeath! if there be no other method I'll chuck old cent. per cent. out of the window and • her •
• t liberty that way.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Come, come, I hope to effect it by ſome leſs furious means—I'll ſlep to him for a few minutes. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Hey-day! what have we here?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: As I live, mother Buſy, and my man Fuſee —married, I hope.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Sir Charles, your moſt humble ſervant —Emmeline, how doſt do child?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And pray, madam, why am I left out of the catalogue of compliments.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: You! marry come up! indeed I wonder you have aſſurance to look me in the face after ſuch behaviour, I ſhould have been prettily off, indeed, if I had depended upon your fine ſpeeches and palav'ring—I ſhould have been a fine laughing truly, for all the coxcombs and gill flirts; but I'd have you know, Mr. Colonel, grown birds are not to be catched with chaff, no, no, I ſaw through all your deſigns.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Deſigns! madam! what could you ſee but the moſt faithful, the moſt ardent paſſion; but I ſuppoſe you tax me with inconſtancy to juſtify your own falſhood, and will give yourſelf away to blaſt all my hopes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Ah, that wheedling tongue, and that deceitful fa • e, if my virtue had not been impregnable, if I had not been as cold as ice to unlawful love, I don't know what might have been the conſequence; but as I am not to be impoſed upon; I know the world, and the difference of people— Captain Spontoon, my huſband, has heard your baſeneſs.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: How! huſband!—ah cruel fair—are you then married.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p:
Yes, truly, Sir—perhaps you thought I could not get a match; but the Captain has diſcernment
—you might have made your market, Sir, but now 'tis too late.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Then, animoſity aſide, I wiſh you joy with all my heart; and hope Fuſee may make you a good huſband.

sp.speaker: Sir. Char. and Emme.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Fuſee! and who's that pray?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A very honeſt fellow I aſſure you, madam, my ſervant that was, and your lord and maſter that is—how long have you been a Captain, Fuſee?

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: Not much above four and twenty hours, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Char. Col. and Emme.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs B.
sp.p: What can all this mean?—how, Sir! are you no Captain?

sp.speaker: Fuſee
sp.p: No truly, not at preſent—but I will be one if you'll buy me a commiſſion, my charming dear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Buy you a halter, my roguiſh dear.

sp.speaker: Sir Char. Col. and Emme.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: What am I tricked then? has neighbour Sly impoſied on me?

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Oh no, madam, you are not to be impoſed upon—you know the world, and the difference of people, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, huſſy, muſt ſuch a minx as you ſet up your face?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Nay, good madam, don't be in a paſſion, it diſcompoſes your beauty—a bride, and frown —oh fie.

sp.speaker: Sir Char and Emme.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. B
sp.p: They provoke me ſo I don't know what to ſay or do—married to his ſervant! well you are pleaſed to be mighty merry, good folks— but I am not the firſt that has been deceived, nor ſh • n't be the laſt—as for you, Colonel, I'll let your character be known; and this fellow I can be revenged of at any time; for if I throw myſelf into the river my jointure goes with me, ſo there's tit for tat, and bite for bite, he! he! he! runs off

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Follow your Lady, Fuſee, ſhe'll come too when ſhe can't help herſelf.

sp.speaker: Fuſee.
sp.p: I'll do what I can, Sir, for ſake of the money; but if ſhe ſhould reſolve upon a lover's leap e'en let her go, for truly I begin to think her ſervice will prove harder duty than the brown muſket and ſix-pence a day. Exit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well, madam, I think her inſolence to you is pretty well repaid.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Thoroughly, as I could wiſh.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Nothing but ſtrict juſtice on your own account, for ſhe was moſt abominably troubleſome —here comes Lady Charlotte and the Knight.

div.stage: ENTER SIR SCRAPEALL and LADY CHARLOTTE.

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p: Well, my Lord, upon ſigning the paper I ſent you to peruſe; you ſhall have my conſent to marry her in writing.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Sir Scrapeall, your very humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p: How! my ſcarlet friend! what ſhall I ſay to him? (aſide) your ſervant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well, Sir Scrapeall, the young Lady agrees to your conſent in my favour.

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p: Conſent, Sir! ay, but—

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: How, Sir! have you been in treaty with another?

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p: In treaty!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Another▪ why, Sir, did not you promiſe me your conſent on abating half the Lady's fortune?

sp.speaker: L. Char.
sp.p: Nay, Colonel, but I abate the whole of her fortune.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Hey day! guardian! have you ſet me up to public ſale?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I ſhall depend upon your word, Sir Scrapeall.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: And I ſhall poſitively inſiſt upon my claim.

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p:
You are very peremptory, gentlemen; but
ſuppoſe I won't conſent to either, what then—as to you, Colonel, I don't think your fortune ſufficient, and for you my Lord—keep our bargain and you ſhall have my conſent to run away with her to Scotland. (aſide)

sp.speaker: L. Char.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! a very honeſt and generous propoſal, indeed, Sir Knight, but—a word in your ear, I have more occaſion for a huſband than a wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p: What! a huſband!

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Yes Sir, that I'll teſtify.

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p: How! are not you a Lord then?

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: No Sir, but I am a Lady by courteſy.

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p: What the miſchief, women turned into men; I have long ſcrupled to believe my ears, and now I ſhan't chuſe to truſt my eyes—well, Colonel, I ſhall conſider your propoſals.

sp.speaker: L Charlo.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, it ſhall be ſettled now, and—draw this way—not only give your conſent but the Lady's whole fortune, or I'll make you repent it.

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p: make me repent it—I defy you, Sir— madam, I mean.

sp.speaker: L Charlo.
sp.p: Softly, Sir, you ſent me a paper to peruſe.

sp.speaker: Sir rcr.
sp.p: And what then?

sp.speaker: L Charlo.
sp.p: You thought it was a releaſe for that Lady's fortune; but liſten to the title—directions for John Ringbolt, maſter of the ſhip Peggy, to run her aſhore, ſhe being inſured at treble value—

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p: Oh that blundering dog, my clerk aſide well, Colonel, ſince I believe you'll make the girl a good huſband, and ſhe is willing, I ſhall give my conſent.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, but it muſt be done in due form; and now as your Lady has many juſt cauſes of complaint, to prevent the trouble, ſcandal, and expence of a public divorce, ſhe propoſes a voluntary ſeparation.

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p: With all my heart, I'll reſign all title to her—let her march as ſoon as ſhe pleaſes.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: And take her whole fortune with her.

sp.speaker: Sir Scra.
sp.p: No, no, I did not ſay that neither.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: What I muſt conſult the inſurers, muſt I. (aſide)

sp.speaker: Sir Scra.
sp.p: Oh—h—h—no, I'll do what you have a mind.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Well gentlemen and ladies, I call upon you as witneſſes, that Sir Scrapeall agrees to a ſeparation propoſed by his Lady, and is ſo generous as to return her whole fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir Scra.
sp.p: Ay, all but the two thouſand pounds her extravagance coſt me.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Oh, the inſurers ſhall ſettle that point.

sp.speaker: Sir Scra.
sp.p: I ſhall certainly run mad—ſtark ſtaring mad—if it was not for the hopes that brother Starboard will drink himſelf dead in a month, and make me his heir, I could never hold out.

sp.speaker: Starb
sp.p: (without) Who's aboard, yo, ho.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: What naval greeting's that?

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: By the harmony of expreſſion it ſhould be Sir Scrapeall's delicate brother-in-law.

div.stage: ENTER STARBOARD and RUELLE, arm in arm.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: (ſinging) And Moll, and Kate, and Nancy ſhall roll in loui's d'ors.—What cheer, what cheer, meſſmates? why brother Brainleſs, your poop always carries a ſignal of diſtreſs; what have you been in a gard gale ſince I ſaw you? meſs, I have ſailed through the channel of courtſhip twelve knots an hour, and made the harbour of matrimony with my little ſnow half a glaſs ſince.

sp.speaker: Sir Scra.
sp.p: How! what! not married, I hope?

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p:
I don't know what you call married, but I ſhowed the parſon a cocquet to clear out of the canonical cuſtom-houſe; he clapped on his uniform,
read grace, ſpliced our hands, and launched us off to ſwing in a hammock together.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Bravely ſaid, honeſt captain.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Mrs. Ruelle I heartily wiſh you joy.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: I am obliged to you, madam.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: Ay, ay, thank you, thank you, young woman, the ſame to you when you ſteer the like courſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Scra.
sp.p: I profeſs I am aſtoniſhed!

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: And why ſo, forſooth? is not ſhe a tight built thing?

sp.speaker: Sir Scra.
sp.p: Well, ſince it is ſo, I deſire you to pay me for the punch and eatables you and your followers have devoured, and the things you have broke.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: Pay! blow me up then this here ſhip of yours is no better than a bum-boat; ſo d'ye ſee, order us a good bucket of rumbo, make your bill, and we'll pay all together—a l • ght heart, &c. (ſings)

sp.speaker: Sir Scra.
sp.p: Oh mercy on me! I muſt follow the mad bear to ſee he does no more miſchief. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! what a rueful condition is the poor Knight in.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Deſervedly—madam you have negotiated and diſtributed juſtice with moſt commendable impartiality.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: The pleaſing effects are amply rewarded, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: And now, my friend, it remains to perfect our own happineſs, which has coſt us ſo much anxiety in the purſuit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
But will, in the hands of theſe ladies, more than repay it all; for how pleaſing ſoever the irregular ſallies of diſſipation may be, I doubt not but we ſhall be perfectly and happily convinced
That human kind no equal bliſs can prove,
To the chaſte raptures of connubial love.
